reviewText: Camp, fun and a great nod and love letter to the silver age way of story telling for comics.BBATB is a show that indulges in the wacky antics of that time in comics that had fun with its source material and not take it so so seriously and make it dark and morbid.The show does occasionally travel into serious tone stories but never loses its feeling of a show that makes uses of the greater DC Comic universe.it uses a lot of DC Comic characters not just Batman.We get to see a revision of Aquaman that has become a fan favorite [if only he got a spin-off] and we get golden age heroes like Plastic Man.This exploration of the DCU is great for fans of the comics, cartoon lovers and those who just want to have fun.
summary: Great show for those looking for fun and creativity

Title: N/A

reviewText: I began watching this show on netflix not that long ago & feel many of the negative reviews here are from individuals who aren't familiar with or appreciate DC's 1950 -1960's era. "Batman Brave & the Bold" is clearly a love letter to DC Comics' silver age. So far it's been nothing but great self contained episodes & dispensing a plethora of characters from their universe no matter how obscure. There's an obvious love here for this particular period by the creators of this show. The Jack Kirbyesque animation fits perfectly with the direction of this cartoon & I'm glad I finally got around to seeing what I had been missing. I feel like at times that Bob Kane & Carmine Infantino's signature should be scrawled somewhere in the background of each episode. This is truly an excellent series.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Batman: The Brave and the Bold is surprisingly fun and entertaining. On the face of it, one could easily assume this series is nothing more than a kids show. Well I did, and I can't believe how wrong I was! Even though my idea of Batman is more along the lines of the dark and brooding detective, maybe even Frank Milller's slightly psycho interpretation. I thoroughly enjoyed the witty & creative stories that are presented in this masterful series.Some of the high points of this show are brilliant voice acting, very high production values, and nice clean animation. It is also full of subtle details and 'inside jokes' that are sure to please Batman fans with knowledge of the character beyond Nolan's movies. I recommend this series to adults that still enjoy animation, light hearted fun, and of course, the super hero genre. What I hate though, is the studio not releasing a box set yet! This series came out back in 2008! stop milking it WB.
summary: Great show, but where's the box set???
Title: N/A

reviewText: At first I was excited about a new Batman cartoon, then I saw one and changed my mind. Then I saw more and changed my mind again.Batman: The Brave and the Bold gets a bit campy at time, and you'd almost expect Batman (voiced by Diedrich Bader) to pull a six-foot laser torch from his utility belt. But it's not as campy as the 60's Adam West show, you just have to adopt a modest suspension of disbelief, and enjoy the ride.All your favorite villains are here as well as heroes too, some of them not given a lot of screen time in the past (Red Tornado, Plastic Man). You have to love the Dick Sprang version of Joker, and Batman's cool CGI car. Wonder about some of the character focus though - Plastic Man seems more believable than Aquaman?Still, it's a respectful treatment of the not-so-dark night, and as usual Andrea Romano brings top talent to the ever expanding DC entertainment universe.If you've got a former comics fan in your family of any age, Batman: The Brave and the Bold Season One, Part One, would be a great gift to let them revisit an old passion. Though it's part one, you still get 13 episodes, for unlike some other cartoon series, the first season was a complete 26 episodes. Great value right here at Amazon.
summary: Love it for what it is

reviewText: Just to get this out of the way; YES! I agree that Warner Bros. is a greedy studio for releasing three single disc DVDs and now the first half of season 1! Then again, when hasn't it? Remember when they were releasing single disc volumes of Batman: The Animated Series then gave us the "season" sets? Same thing goes for Justice League and JLU. And let's not forget Disney! Lord knows fans of the Power Rangers series are upset because Europe and other overseas markets get complete season sets while we don't even get one FULL season (Operation Overdrive aside). But honestly, fans of this show are getting much better treatment than fans of Ben 10: Alien Force, whose three seasons are stretched across 9 single disc releases.Now on to the show itself! I just get a kick out of this show! Why? Because it doesn't take itself too seriously to the point that its melodramatic (The Dark Knight and Under The Red Hood). Don't get me wrong, I love those movies along with the original animated series (including DTVs spin-offs) and (to the shock of Bat-Fans) The Batman but, and I may be completely wrong in saying this, there are too few fans who like and can appreciate different interpretations of Batman over the character's 70 years of existence. This particular interpretation, while lighter in tone and using tongue-in-cheek humor, doesn't descend into outright parody of the characters. While I love Batman: TAS with its mature storytelling and complex characters (and will probably never be topped as the definitive version of Batman), this is quickly pushing its way as being my favorite animated Batman series. And not to mention its one of the few shows that makes Cartoon Network watchable.The Golden and Silver Age of Comics are my favorite periods of the superhero (along with several stories of the 70s, 80s and 90s). Up until a certain point (I'd say around when Dr. Wertham's book was first published) comics were treated seriously (albeit not as serious as today) but the stories still felt like an adventure, unlike now when everything just feels like a soap opera and you need to purchase God knows how many different books just to follow ONE STORYLINE!!! And that's just one appeal that the series has for me. The stories feel like an adventure and are fun to watch just as the early comics were fun to read. Though I will say that not all of the episodes featured here are great but there are a few elements that make it enjoyable. Terror on Dinosaur Island was a little too goofy (though the backstory of Plastic Man was a nice touch), Enter the Outsiders was pointless (but Wildcat was a great co-star), Journey to the Center of the Bat was weird (Aquaman, Atom and Platelete saved that one) and Return of the Fearsome Fangs was goofy and pointless (though like Plastic Man, delving into Batman's past was good). The highlights (for me anyway) were Rise of the Blue Beetle, Evil Under The Sea, Invasion of the Secret Santas, Dawn of the Deadman, Fall of the Blue Beetle and the two-part episodes featuring Owlman. Day of the Dark Knight and The Eyes of Despero weren't good or memorable but they weren't bad. Just OK (Green Arrow was annoying in that episode and I really hate Guy Gardner). But one thing that I absolutely love is the references to the Adam West series! Ever since all the DC superhero cartoons started, every other DC show had a reference or two but never one reference to this series (I don't count the one segment in the episode Legends of the Dark Knight since they were really paying tribute to the art of Dick Sprang). In Day of the Dark Knight, most of the villains trying to escape are made up of the ones seen in the series; King Tut, Egghead, Bookworm, Shame, Marsha Queen of Diamonds, Siren, Black Widow, Ma Parker, Louie the Lilac, The Mad Hatter (David Wayne version), False Face, Archer and Clock King (when he gets hit, his face is that of Walter Slezak). The title of the two-part episodes, Deep Cover For Batman and Game Over For Owlman, is a reference to their titles (which were almost always two-part episodes that had similar, rhyming titles). Also in Game Over For Owlman, after Joker sees that Batman's devoted a wing of his trophy room to him, Batman reminisces about previous traps he's been in; a giant key duplicator (ep. 55 The Impractical Joker), strapped to a slot machine rigged electric chair (ep. 15 Joker Goes To School) and a giant clam (ep. 72 The Joker's Hard Times). Even later in the episode another Joker trap is referenced when Owlman tempts Joker to trap Batman in wax (a fate that almost befell Robin in ep. 55).The heroes, villains and the buildings reflect how they appeared back in the 50s and 60s, which again is fun. It blends the nostalgia of those times with the modern conveniences of today. My only problem is Batman's costume, not how it looks but how it functions. I don't get how he can have a flowing cape which in turn can either turn into a jetpack or shorten itself for underwater exploration. Even back when all the weird things were happening back in the 50s, I don't think his costume ever did that. My favorite pieces of animation though are probably the Bat-vehichles. As stated, I love the retro-feel of the series and seeing the Batmobile reminded me almost immediately of the Adam West series. Even better was that in Game Over For Owlman, after the villain takes control of the car, Batman relies on the 1940s Batmobile to take him down. Though I do find it weird that its able to transform into the Bat-Plane which can transform into the Bat-Boat which can transform into the Bat-Sub. I didn't know Batman had access to Transformer technology.The voice acting is fantastic in this series proving once again that Andrea Romano knows how to pick the right people. Dierdrich Bader voices Batman this time around and, like the series itself, has become one of my favorite Batman voices. His interpretation is a defender of the law and doesn't mind using a one-liner to take out the villain. The guest cast is also superb, particular praise for John DiMaggio as Aquaman, who was always an OK guest in JL/JLU but he never stood out. DiMaggio's version is fun and adventurous. Also praise for Jeff Glen Bennett as the Joker who's more deadpan and wittier than previous incarnations and he really brings this 50s-esque version of the character to life.All in all its a fun series for fans of the older comics/TV series (when S1, vol. 2 comes out, Batman: TAS will get some references) and this is a Batman/superhero series that parents don't have to worry about when their kids watch it and can enjoy it with them as well.

reviewText: Nothing irritates me more than ignorant fanboys ruining the reputation of an excellent program because they can't comprehend how prices work. All they see is "Season 1, Part 1" and they foam at the mouth and begin to rant about "greedy corporations" trying to steal their money.Let me break it down for you. Batman: The Brave and the Bold Season 1, Part 1 is 13 episodes, on 2 DVDs, and is currently prices at $15.49. Keep in mind that the Amazon price fluctuates, I've seen it as cheap as $14.99.Now comprate that toJustice League Unlimited - Season Two (DC Comics Classic Collection). Justice League Unlimited Season 2 is 13 episodes, on 2 DVDs, for 14.99.Again:- 13 episodes of BBatB are worth 15.49- 13 episodes of JLU  are worth 14.99They're just complaining because one is a complete season, and the other is a half season. But, they're BOTH 13 EPISODES!!!By now, you should know what Batman: The Brave and the Bold is like. It's a lighter take on the caped crusader. If you're the type of fan that loved Nolan's The Dark Knight, or grew up watching Batman the Animated Series, and you like a serious Batman, then you'll want to skip this series and buyBatman: Under the Red Hood (Two-Disc Special Edition).The rest of us, we love us some campy, almost-Adam-West-like, adventures with the Dark Knight. I never would have imagined Diedrich Bader as Batman. He's no Kevin Conroy, but Bader's voice fits the show's premise. What really makes BBatB stand out is the creator's devotion to feature superheroes and villains that have had very little appearances outside of the comics: Calender Man, Kite Man, the Top, Plastic Man, the Blue Beetle, Kamandi, and Bronze Tiger.Further, let me answer some questions you might be asking:1. No, Kevin Conroy is not Batman in this.2. No, this does not contain the "Bat-Mite Episode" AKA "Legends of the Dark-Mite." That won't be until Part 2.3. No, this does not contain the musical episode with Neil Patrick Harris. That's in Part 2, "Mayhem of the Music Meister"4. No, this doesn't have "the one with Kevin Conroy in it." That's episode 37, "Chill of the Night." It also has Adam West, Mark Hamill and Julie Newmar. That's part of Season 2.That's a lot of 'No's. But it's still worth $15 if you can pick it up at a local retailer. My favorite episodes are "Evil Under the Sea," "Fall of the Blue Beetle" "Deep Cover for Batman" and "Game Over for Owlman." So pick it up if you like superhero action, and I hope I've helped you make an informed decision.
summary: How to Judge a DVD release

reviewText: The five stars is for the show. If you're a comic geek, you'll actually love this show because it grows on you.Here's why the split seasons thing is NOT a big deal. You are getting 13 episodes. Yes, Season 1 was 26 episodes. The thing is, that is DOUBLE the normal amount of episodes newer cartoons have been coming out as, and quite frankly if you look at DVDs of other new Warner Bros cartoons like "What's New Scooby-Doo" and "The Batman" each season is approximately only 13 episodes. So you are getting your money's worth. They most likely will not release a full 26 episode season set, and if they do it'd cost like $40 like the old Batman The Animated Series boxsets used to.The pattern is, they release 13 episode seasons or collections. They start off costing about $15. Eventually they go down to $9 to $10 (seasons of both "What's New Scooby-Doo" and "The Batman" have hit those marks both online and in stores).Sure, it's not the complete season. Yet the complete season is really like two seasons already. I'd rather buy 13 episodes than buy those discs with only 4 episodes each on them.The reason Season 2 of Gargoyles didn't get a Volume 2 release? Too many customers like me realized we paid $20 for Season 1 and then half of Season 2 was over $30. I won't pay over $30 for only half a season, and it took way too long to come down in price.This half season set is still a good deal when you realize you're getting the same number of episodes that are full seasons of "The Batman". 13 episodes isn't too shabby. If you don't buy this set though, who knows if they'll release Vol. 2 with the other 13 episodes, and then the first 13 episodes of Season 2? If the third season is only going to be 13 episodes as reported, then Season 3 would be a full season set, whereas it'll be two-parters for the first two seasons...equaling five sets of 13 episodes just like "The Batman".
summary: Split Seasons Does Not Matter This Time

reviewText: - Plastic Man: "Are you seeing what I'm seeing? 'Cause I'm seeing gorillas riding pterodactyls with harpoon guns, stealing a boat."- Batman: "It's Gorilla Grodd."- Plastic Man: "It's messed up is what it is!"For a brooding crimefighting loner, Batman sure teams up a lot. And I guess this incarnation finds him brooding not as often as you'd think. What we get in this animated series seems to be the Silver Age incarnation of Batman (guy's even drawn like the '50s & '60s version), and this is a different, more gregarious, sunnier kind of cat. Frank Miller would probably have a hissy fit. The featured stories are set in contemporary times, and yet it's clearly a mash-up of the old and the new. Batman hangs out with the likes of the new Blue Beetle, but when the Green Arrow drops in, the beardless archer is sporting his old classic Golden Age duds.There's a breezier tone. Check out that gonzo, jazzy theme music! - and the outlandish plots and the lots of exuberant punching and kicking, comic book style. For those who've imprinted on the more angsty, angrier, darker Dark Knight, this type of cheery takes a bit of getting used to. Kids will enjoy what's on the surface. But this show also has something for the grown-ups and the hardcore DC Comics fans.BATMAN: THE BRAVE AND THE BOLD Season One, Part One comes in two discs and contains the first thirteen episodes. And because Season One comprises 26 episodes, this means that the set is officially only half as good. Still, the nifty rotating cast of heroes and the cool character designs and that delightful whiff of camp are things to savor. These are mostly stand-alone episodes, and I love that each episode starts out with a mini-adventure that teams Batman up with a fellow DC character, and that it ends before the opening credits and mostly doesn't have anything to do with the central story. You never do know which cape & cowl is going to step up in any given episode. The writers are careful to guest star not only the more well-known superheroes but the obscure ones, as well. The new Blue Beetle, Jaime Reyes, is featured prominently. Aquaman, braggadocious and bold, is given the best treatment since possibly ever. This Batman is voiced by Diedrich Bader (also known as that creepy guy in OUTSOURCED). Bader has got Kevin Conroy's timber and cadences down pat to the extent that I initially assumed it was Conroy just picking up where he left off.The only bonus feature is "Lego Harry Potter." It's pretty much what you think it is.Brief plot breakdowns now for the 13 episodes. If you're a stickler about not knowing even the most basic reveals, then consider yourself ***SPOILERS*** alerted:- Episode 101 - "The Rise of the Blue Beetle!" - In the pre-opening credits segment, Batman and Green Arrow go up against the Clock King. Then Batman and the new Blue Beetle fly thru a wormhole in space and end up on a distant planet where Blue Beetle is deified by that world's cute amoeba cell-like inhabitants.- Episode 102 - "Terror on Dinosaur Island!" - Batman and Fire frustrate the Gentleman Ghost while Plastic Man was elsewhere, stuffing his pants with loot. Then Batman and Plastic Man are stranded on a mysterious island that stands outside of time... and has dinosaurs.- Episode 103 - "Evil Under the Sea!" - Bats foils Felix Faust's scheme to open Pandora's Box, with the help of a surprise guest (you don't find out who until the end). Then Batman journeys under the sea to visit Aquaman in Atlantis, just in time to save Aquaman from an assassin. Surely, Aquaman's sinister brother Orm had nothing to do with this?- Episode 104 - "Invasion of the Secret Santas!" - Batman and Blue Beetle take on Sportsmaster in a bowling alley. Then the robot hero Red Tornado tries to get with the Christmas spirit except that, well, you know, dude's a robot. Batman is no help; he's got his own holiday issues. Meanwhile, flying saucers from Neptune invade Earth, and these aliens demand Santa Claus. Or is this a trick being played by Fun Haus?- Episode 105 - "Day of the Dark Knight!" - The Green Lantern Corps requests Batman's assistance in keeping Guy Gardner's nose clean, but then Guy gets into it with a tiny alien prisoner. Then Merlin Ambrosius, seeking aid against Morgan Le Fay and Jason Blood, plucks Batman and Green Arrow from the modern age and into 5th century Britain. It's all very Camelot-y.- Episode 106 - "Enter the Outsiders!" - Batman and B'wana Beast stymie the Black Manta's crime caper. Then Golden Age old-timer, Wildcat, fresh off a heart attack, horns in on Batman's attempt to take down the unruly Outsiders (who are teenagers in this incarnation, and also are kind of all villainy).- Episode 107 - "Dawn of the Dead Man!" - In the far-flung blasted future, Kamandi the Last Boy on Earth helps Batman make off with some antibiotics. Then, in London, Boston Brand (a.k.a. "Deadman") teams up with Batman's astral projected self when Batman's body is buried alive by the Gentleman Ghost and the coffin rendered booby-trapped. Hope no one's run out of nth metal.- Episode 108 - "Fall of the Blue Beetle!" - First, the flashback adventure featuring Bats and the Silver Age Blue Beetle (that'd be Ted Kord). Then teenager Jaime Reyes, the new Blue Beetle, digs into his predecessor's history and arrives at a sinister plot to take over the world.- Episode 109 - "Journey to the Center of the Bat!" - Bats, Plastic Man and Elongated Man provide the long arm of the law against Babyface. Then, to remedy a Chemo-infected Caped Crusader, Atom shrinks himself and Aquaman down to microscopic size and they infiltrate Batman's body.- Episode 110 - "The Eyes of Despero!" - Batman and Dr. Fate thwart Wotan's plan to control the Library of Infinity. Then, with the Green Lantern Corps having fallen under Despero's sway, it falls to Batman and the last three free Lanterns to save the day. But what if these Lanterns were Guy Gardner, Sinestro... and G'Nort?- Episode 111 - "Return of the Fearsome Fangs!" - Inexplicably in the Old West, in a Sergio Leone backdrop, that squirrely-eyed bounty hunter Jonah Hex and Batman corral the Royal Flush Gang. Then, in China, Batman and the prideful Bronze Tiger seek vengeance against Fox and the Shadow Clan for killing their old martial arts master. "You kill my teachaaa!"- Episode 112 - "Deep Cover for Batman! (Part 1)" - The Injustice Syndicate, sinister doppelgangers of Batman and his superhero pals, aim to make use of a bridge to parallel Earths to cross over to Gotham. But not if Batman beats them to the punch. To quote Bats: "The resemblance to my friends is uncanny. Like looking into a funhouse mirror... of evil."- Episode 113 - "Game Over for Owlman! (Part 2)" - Batman returns to his own reality and finds himself a wanted felon, thanks to Owlman, a parallel version of the Dark Knight. With every meta-human do-gooder out to nab him, it's maybe time to team up with a certain Clown Prince of Crime.
summary: Silver Age Batman plonked in the 21st Century, and Aquaman gets a personality makeover

reviewText: I've gotta add some positivity here only because there are some people I'm sure who will see this entry and think two stars confirms their suspicions about BATB not being a good show, because it is not Batman:TAS from the '90s.  Nothing could be TAS, of course, but just because this is a lighter series that embraces Silver Age sensibilities and a little of the camp of the '60s-era Batman doesn't mean it is not fun and very entertaining.  One needs to only track down Bat-Mite's speech from this show to really understand what BATB is all about.BATB is an improvement over the last Batman series (The Batman), at least for hardcore comic fans.  While the latter was aimed at 2000s-style younger viewers, BATB has a lot of nods to longtime fans or ones who've delved into past eras of the DC Universe.  And hey, it made Aquaman cool, what more can you ask for?????  (And wait till we get to the Music Meister episode)The split season sets are not necessary, but I'll brave it to get a collection of this series.
summary: OUTRAGEOUS!  (The show and maybe the split seasons, but I won't let that ruin things)

reviewText: My review will cover two parts.  First let's talk about the show. When I first heard about it, I had my doubts.  I grew up on the great "Batman: The Animated Series" and loved "The Batman," especially at the end.  But when this came out I first thought they had ran out of ideas for Batman.  I was wrong, it mixes action like from the last two shows and adds in humor in such a perfect amount for Batman that it comes off as enjoyable instead of cheesy.Now as for the release.  I agree with everyone else here, this should be the FULL season one.  I hate when the studio release half a season of a show.  Disney did it with "Gargoyles: Season Two," and Warner has done it with "The Real Adventures of Johnny Quest: Season One, both of which may never see the rest of their season on DVD.  Warner has also done it with other shows like "Tiny Toons"and "Smurfs."  Is it a cheep underhand move to try and force the consumer to fork over more money then they would for releasing these seasons whole?  Sure is.  Is it right?  Nope, in fact it turns consumers off.  But that fact is the way these studios think, if this set does not sell, good luck seeing much more of this show on DVD, even if it is Batman.  "Gargoyles" and "Real Adventures of Johnny Quest" have shown that already.Bottom line, despite how wrong it may be, if you love this show and want to see more of it on DVD, buy this release.
Title: N/A

reviewText: While there was much to gripe about with the prior releases of Batman: The Brave And The Bold, the new setup with the first season split over two sets works well because of the price point.  It'd be wonderful to get the full season in a $20 box, but beggars can't be choosers and the current release is far superior to how they released the series in the past.For the series itself, it is terrific.  It's not the more serious incarnation of Batman that we saw in The Animated Series.  Nor is it a 'tweener series like The Batman was.  Both of those incarnations of Batman on the small screen also were great, tackling different aspects and generations of the character.B:TBATB is no different.  This is pure, unadulterated Silver Age Batman executed wonderfully.  The show is tons of fun and a load of laughs with plenty of action thrown in.  We get to see so many members of the DC universe take the screen in a show that is all about having a good time and awakening the fun you found in comics as a child.I love the look of the show.  The voice talent works very well.  And they manage to make the show not be cheesy at all, unlike the old Superfriends shows or even the Batman live action series from the 60s.  A balance is struck here.Like others, I wasn't sure if I'd like this show.  I'm glad that I've watched it and gotten to see another aspect of Batman take the screen.  He is, without a doubt, the greatest comic book character ever.

reviewText: If you liked the look of Batman in the 1950's and early 19"60's and if you liked the early Batman team-ups in the DC Comics series "The Brave and the Bold" from the mid-1960's, then you will like this "Warner Brothers animated cartoon series."Bat-Mite" the mystical imp from the Fifth Dimension who is an avid admirer of Batman, a chracter from the 1960's and early 1960's Batman comics, appears in one of the episodes.The series incorporates tongue-in-cheek humor and is also more ki-friendly.Ace the bat-Hound, another character from the Batman comics of the 1950's and early 1960's, also appear in some of the episodes in the series.The Professor with the time machine that appeared in a number of Batman stories in the 1950's and early 1960's also appears in an episode or two.Robin also appears in an episode as Batman and an adult Robin face off aginst a Batman villian of the 1950's, Crazy Quilt.There is also a regular tongue-in-=cheek rivalry between Batman and Green Arrow.  The original early version of Green Arrow is used.  The original early version was more of a take-off on Batman.  Green Arrow has an Arrow-Car, Arrow-Plane, Arrow-Cave, Arrow-Signal, etc.Aquaman is portrayed as a big blow hard, a mariner who likes tro brag about his wonderful exploits.  He can go on and onand onand on.This series has the best version of Plastic Man since the 1940's when Plastic Man" was done by Jack Cole for Quality Comis.In an episode in whic hBatman teams up with Kamandi, The Lst Boy on Earth, in the future.  in the Bat-Cave encounters the mutated Bat-Men creatures that appeared in a 1950's story of Batman.I wold have liked to see two more characters from the Batman comics of the 1960's and early 1960's appear in an episode of this series, Bat-Woman (AKA Billionair heiress Kathy Kane) and her teenage sidekick, the original Bat-Girl (Kathy Kane's neice).Even though this series uses the look of the Batman of the 1950's and early 1960's, current characters and spects of teh current DC Comics and heroes are also incorporated into the series.I realize that there are people out there that are not keen on the Batman of the 1950's and early 1960's and prefer the current darker and grittier Batman of today and are not into the tongue-in-cheek humor used in the series.  However, if you do like the Batman of the 1950's and early 1960's and like tongue-in-cheek humor, you will like this series.  Again the series is also more kid-friendly.
summary: Batman: The Brave and The Bold Vol.s 1 and2 (Batman:  The Look O the 1960's and Early 1960's)

reviewText: Wow! I am hooked! I watched my first episode January 2013, and I liked it so much I went and bought the whole series! I have a few gripes and likes about the series, but hey, one thing to consider: Look at the stars I gave it... 4 Stars! not bad.  If I didn't bother telling what I like or disliked about the series, that would show I don't care for it, and it will collect dust for many years to come or unless I sell it.  I like this series quite a bit! The opening theme plays the style of music Batman should have.  It's a detective theme.  Kind of a different take on Peter Gunn, Henry mancinni.  Not quite james Bond, too slow.  But this one was like The Incredibles Credits. Fun! Colorful! Full of imagination! It makes me wonder if Disney is trying to buy out DC.  Two things I am disappointed in...Has nothing to do with this series... It's DC.VS. Marvel!.Why can't DC do as good with their heroes in movies as marvel has? I am not looking forward to Justice league movie.  Avenger II I am looking forward to.  What ever happened to Batman 1966 series?! Is time going to run out for anybody who would remember the series before DC gets off of their rear ends and release the series on DVD??? Oh sure, lets complain about copyrights on 1950's music... Music thje series already paid for just like happy days and still they changed the music in happy days starting with season 2! Music industry stinks! Ruining our favorite TV shows with false music! I had to say something.... Sorry....

reviewText: The title of my review says it all. I hate this show, even more than I hated the final season of Batman: TAS, which is where the slide downslope began to happen for me. Look, I like a good joke as much as the next guy, but I have always, always had a problem with camp houmour.When the material starts not to take itself seriously, then you begin to wonder if A: the creators ran out of fresh ideas, or B: the creators themselves undervalue the properties' inherent worth. That Bruce Timm loves the material, I don't question. But in one of Batman: TAS' commentary tracks he happened to mention that Batman Forever is his all time favorite movie. Batman Forever? Really? Not the Tim Burton movies? Not the Christopher Nolan Films? The campy one in the middle?Those first three years of Batman: TAS where a direct response to the Tim Burton Films and must have had some editorial guidence from the studio (something, I'll admit, I'm not usually in favor of). But with the popularity of the show established, and the studio pretty much leaving him on his own to do his thing, we get the full force of BRUCE TIMM UNLEASHED!The result? Cheese left to grow mold, mold left to grow entirely new unheard of life forms that develop thier own civilization (art, politics, commerce, weapons! for God's sake!) that will eventually rise up from the cheese, take over the world, and make us their puppet slaves!And it will all be Bruce Timm's fault. It begins here. Don't let the cheese grow. Don't buy the cheese. Don't even come near the cheese! If you like the cool Batman, this aint it!
summary: The show is so cheesy, the fungi growth has spawned an entirely new civilization!
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I first heard of Batman: The Brave and the Bold, I was excited. Then I saw some pictures and got worried. Then I saw a video clip. My fears were confirmed. This wasn't my Batman.So I never watched it. I did hear good things about it though, and considering my favorite C-list DC comic characters appear in it, when the opportunity came up for me to review Batman: The Brave and the Bold: Season One , Part One , I decided to give it a chance. And now I regret not watching this show earlier. It's fantastically entertaining.More than that, it's fun. Batman: The Brave and the Bold exists in the present the way 80's action cartoons exist in the memory. That is: You remember them being good, but they don't hold up when you actually watch them. But Batman: The Brave and the Bold does hold up, right now and today, and it feels just like you remember the 80's action cartoons feeling like.I was worried a light-hearted take on Batman would make him into a joke like Adam West did and I'm sure I wasn't the only one. Thankfully, Batman is played straight and given only a dry sense of humor, pretty much the way the modern fans remember him. He just throws around a few on-liners, and that is all. Even if that turns you off, this show gets so much right. Aquaman is played for laughs here, just like he always should be, and it also introduces tons of awesome C-list characters like Blue Beetle, Deadman, Red Tornado, Wildcat and many others to a public who probably never heard of them. In fact, if you're a DC comic fan, one of the best part of this show will be the insane number of obscure characters from the comics that show up, which will be sure to make any geek happy.Puncheminnaface!The show deals with some pretty serious subject matter as well, such as death. Examples include the episode "Invasion of the Secret Santas!", which shows the death of Thomas and Martha Wayne, and my personal favorite episode of the collection, "Fall of the Blue Beetle!", where it's shown that not every hero always makes it, and sometimes one has to die. Pretty heavy stuff for a supposedly light, colorful looking kids show.The finale uses Owlman as the main villain. I don't know if Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths came out before this episode or not, but thankfully even though both utilize the same villain and both involve multiple earths, both feel like separate stories. Owlman's plot in Batman: The Brave and the Bold does feel oddly similar to the plan of the Justice Lords in the Justice League episode "A Better World". Still, it does make for an entertaining episode and a satisfying finale.The voice work is fantastic, and while nobody will beat Kevin Conroy, Diedrich Bader does a brilliant job as Batman. John William DiMaggio plays a hilarious Aquaman and Batman Beyond's Will Friedle plays Blue Beetle III wonderfully. In fact, all of the voices seem spot on. It would seem Andrea Romano did a fantastic job, as always.Someday, my son, this will all be yours!The designs are well animated and the style seems to fit the mood of the show. Not to mention it looks absolutely stunning in widescreen. The discs have English and French subtitles, but unfortunately this set has no special features aside from a LEGO Harry Potter trailer (on the main menu for some reason), which is a real bummer. It really could've used a commentary or two, or perhaps a featurette on the wide array of heroes who guest starred in the episode included here. At least we got a stunning transfer.Batman: The Brave and the Bold isn't my Batman, but that doesn't mean I can't watch it and enjoy it for what it is. It's like the Adam West version of Batman. That's my dad's Batman, and even though I don't consider it mine, that doesn't mean I don't watch it and enjoy the heck out of it. Give Batman: The Brave and the Bold a chance. It may not be your Batman, but it will be someone's. See if you can enjoy it for what it is.
summary: He's not my Batman, but that's OK
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are many comic fans, a group that includes yours truly, who feel as though Bruce Timm's 1992 Batman The Animated Series Batman: TAS) so thoroughly covered (and accurately portrayed) the franchise that further animated incarnations were simply no longer necessary.  Over time, the next decade in fact, the team responsible for Batman The Animated Series would somehow manage to evolve the property enough to keep it fresh and in many cases, even improve upon the formula.  We would enjoy Batman Beyond and the "caped crusader's" legacy again as a staple of both the Justice League series (and to a lesser degree in Justice League Unlimited).  Even to this day that incarnation of Batman lives on in the form of the DCAU's frequent animated feature films such as Batman Under the Red Hood, Justice League Crisis on Two Earths, Superman/ Batman Public Enemies, Superman/ Batman Apocalypse and so on.However, and banking on the success of the live-action Batman film reboot (with Christian Bale), Warner saw fit to give viewers another animated version of the franchise, this time opting for a weekly Saturday morning affair.  What resulted was The Batman (2004-2008); a brighter, younger take on the Bruce Wayne character that, while true to many of the characters given their proper due in Batman: TAS, was generally rejected by fans for its light hearted take on dark material and inconsistency (especially in the Rogues Gallery).As such I, like many, feared for the worst when news broke back in late 2007 that Warner Brothers was going to reboot the animated Batman franchise once again.  This latest incarnation, which would be known as The Brave and the Bold, would be a brighter incarnation than the last with even lighter underlying tones.  Teaser shots at the time depicted Batman back in his bright blue, yellow and gray motif, eerily reminiscent of the get-up worn the 1960s Adam West live action series, or more disturbing still, his 1970s/ early 80s Superfriends persona.  This one would have to be an absolute disaster right? Wrong!After just a few episodes (which were now appearing in a Friday primetime slot in Cartoon Network's lineup), Brave and the Bold managed to obliterate any and all preconceived notions of failure.For starters there is the show's unique format to consider; each episode actually consists of a small self-contained team-up adventure before the opening theme then a full length adventure to follow, usually containing an entirely separate hero for which to be teamed up with Batman and villain(s) in need of some justice.  Episodes are structured as stand-alone although there are hints of ongoing story threads explored here and there (as well as a few two-parters for good measure).Just as had been forecasted, the look of the show is extremely bright and crisp, with color pallets seemingly directly from the pages of a comic book.  Interestingly, neither Kevin Conroy's (Batman: TAS) nor Rino Romano's (The Batman) voice talent was utilized for this show, instead calling upon Diedrich Bader of Drew Carry fame to provide the vocals for the titular character.  Many of the secondary characters from the past Batman franchises mentioned above do make frequent appearances here however.So just what makes The Brave and the Bold formula work despite doing away with nearly every aspect of what made Batman: TAS so incredible you ask?  It actually manages to prevent falling into a pattern of overusing its hero and villains for that matter by structuring each episode as a team-up.  In a very legitimate sense, the show has more in common with say Justice League than it does the other Batman incarnations.  Among the notable team-ups in this collection, expect Blue Beetle, Red Tornado, Atom, Green Arrow, (and a truly hilarious take on) Aquaman to mention a few.Next up, it may approach matters lighter than the earlier incarnations but it doesn't do so at the expense of Bruce Wayne/ Batman's intelligence and nor does it overlook his dry, ironic wit.  There is humor scattered about here but no child-like slapstick involved in effort to try and gain approval from the younger set.  Most of the conflicts require brains and Batman's abilities as a detective to thwart as well as the brawn often provided by Batman's episodic sidekick.The look of the characters (both hero and villain) comes straight out of the 1960s-70s comic pages as well, but don't let the lack of updating throw you, they are portrayed in the absolute best possible combination of their original persona blended with modern-day depth (no fear of Superfriends-style group laughter to fade endings here).DCAU alumni James Tucker is the producer of the show and brings with him an apparent deal of respect for the character as a whole as well as their past efforts in Batman: TAS and seems to literally go the extra mile in not attempting a redo of what has already been accomplished there.  Instead, Brave and the Bold brings a much-appreciated modern take on the classic characters out of the comics from yesteryear.Warner Brothers tried initially to pacify fans of the show by dropping 4-episode releases (meaning 6-sets would have to be purchased to have one full 26-episode season) but quickly followed that poor decision up with double disc 13-episode releases.  At the time of this review's writing the first season has been released on DVD entirely as well as the first half (13-episodes) of the second season.  The show is still running on Cartoon Network and is currently broadcasting its third season.In all, I came away from this show very pleasantly surprised.  There is a subtle rhythm to the episodes that is terribly addicting once the viewer becomes accustomed to the format, style and era being represented.  Be forewarned though, completion of this set will lead to having no choice but to acquire the rest.  Here's hoping Warner wastes little time in bringing the rest of the seasons to DVD.
summary: A Refreshing Take on a Beloved Franchise

reviewText: The Dark Knight returns in Cartoon Network's new animated adventure series "Batman: The Brave and the Bold". From the streets of Gotham City to the farthest reaches of the Galaxy, Batman (Diedrich Bader) has proven his courage and skills in the relentless pursuit of justice, but even the World's Greatest Detective needs sometimes a little heroic help. In this collection of 13 episodes of the show's first season, Batman joins forces with Aquaman, Blue Beetle, Plastic Man, Red Tornado, Green Arrow, Wildcat, Deadman, Bronze Tiger and the Atom for some exciting adventures against evildoers of Earth and beyond. Based on the comic book series published by DC Comics, this light adaptation offers an amusing mix of old-school comic book action and refreshing humor. One of the most interesting elements in "Batman: The Brave and the Bold" is that it features lesser-known characters of the DC Universe that haven't been showcased in previous animated shows. The 2-disc DVD set includes such standout episodes like "Day of the Dark Knight!", "Dawn of the Dead Man!", "The Eyes of Despero!", "Deep Cover for Batman!" and "Game Over for Owlman!".For those who have already purchased the three individual discs, you have no need to pick-up "Batman: The Brave and the Bold: Season One, Part One" 2-disc DVD set. The first 13 episodes of the animated series are presented in 1.78:1 anamorphic widescreen format. Both picture quality and 2.0 Dolby Digital audio are pretty good. The interactive menus are simple and easy to navigate. Besides a promo of the new "Lego Harry Potter" game, there are no extras on this 2-disc set. At least, the three individual discs contain optional language tracks and trailers of other Warner Brothers animated releases. Though I'm somewhat disappointed with the general presentation, "Batman: The Brave and the Bold: Season One, Part One" is a decent bargain purchase and scores a "C+".
Title: N/A

reviewText: Wow, the amount of venom being spewed in these pre-release reviews is simply stunning (and why does Amazon open some products to pre-release reviews and not others? Baffling). While I can certainly understand everyone's disappointment at this set not containing a full season, let's clear up some misconceptions:- What constitutes a full "season" in animation is extremely subjective - a network may order 26-episodes up front to fast-track production time, especially with a proven property like Batman. However, these 26 episodes may be broken into two 13-episode seasons, or aired in random bursts sporadically with no real seasonal pattern (Cartoon Network is infamous for doing this with many of the DC shows). I remember early press describing the 13 episodes collected on this set as "Season 1," and in fact the last two episodes here (Deep Cover For Batman/Game Over For Owlman) were designed as a season-ender. So really, what it boils down to is that WHV's description of this set as "Season 1 Part 1" is misleading and based on arbitrary production terminology, and judging by the responses here, incredibly stupid. To simply call this set "Volume 1" would've probably been a much more valid description. No story arcs have been cut off midway, if that's to be a concern.- I see no evidence of Warner Bros. trying to rip anyone off. The suggested retail price and Amazon's standard discount line up exactly with past 13-episode sets of DC animated shows. Do a quick search for either The Batman or Teen Titans, and you'll see some have been discounted, while others are actually a little pricer. Multiply the price of this set x2 for your 26 episodes, and it's still lower than the price we initially paid for the B:TAS volumes a few years back. This doesn't look like a deluxe release by any means, so it seems to fall into WB's standard pricing patterns.- Bought the initial single-disc releases and now you don't know what to do with them? Suck it up. WHV's already pulled this trick before, and you're fooling yourself if you didn't see it coming. If you're just anxious to own the latter episodes (including the musical episode), be patient. The Brave and the Bold isn't quite done on TV yet, so we might still be seeing an erratic release schedule regardless.With that out of the way, this is a great show and I'm looking forward to picking this up. Despite being geared towards kids, I always figured Batman: The Brave and the Bold actually attracted the much older, comics-fluent crowd that understands all the Silver Age references and can appreciate the lighthearted tone (whereas kids probably gravitate towardsThe Dark Knightversion of Batman for being darker and cooler). B:TBATB also unleashes a whole new side of the DC Universe that wasn't covered in the Justice League cartoons -Plastic Man, the Guy Gardner Green Lantern, two Blue Beetles and the Ryan Choi Atom all get exposure here, and there's lots of other surprises along the way. Anyone curious to check out the show's inspiration should look intoShowcase Presents: The Brave and the Bold - The Batman Team-Ups, Vol. 1which reprints the early stories in affordable black-and-white.So yes - it's not the 26-episode set everyone wanted, but it's a perfectly reasonable release and if you didn't pick up the single discs already, this is a highly recommended purchase.
summary: A Great Show and Great Set (And Here's Why)

reviewText: NOTHING and no incarnation of Batman can or will ever beat the original dark gritty 1990's season one of Batman: The Animated Series, kind of like the original 1990's animated X-Men, Superman, and Spider-Man cartoons. (Can't remember if I saw the 1990's Fantastic Four, only saw a couple episodes of the 1990's Incredible Hulk). Anyways, the ONE GREAT thing I am pleased to announce is that this show is FAR SUPERIOR to the 2004's disappointment The Batman, which was COMPLETELY child oriented, while Batman: The Brave and the Bold is kid oriented as well, it also is appealing to adults alike, I think because this show is not childishly stupid like the 2004 one was, and is actually kind of fun really, it is well worth watching, both season one and two, both parts as well, of coarse. It could have been better, I wish Two-Face went head to head with Batman in his own episode as opposed to just having a brief appearance in the opening of a couple episodes in the show, I mean, he looked really great, better than what he looked like when season 4 of Batman: The Animated Series ruined everything.Batman: The Brave and the Bold - Season One, Part One *** out of *****Violent Content: 3/10 - Strong Stylized Action Violence.
summary: WORSE than the 1990's season one of Batman: The Animated Series, BETTER than 2004's The Batman!

reviewText: When I first heard of this show I,like so many other close-minded purists, dismissed it as a shameless attempt to cash in on the theoretical kid market. Once I sat down to watch it, I was pleasantly surprised to see that I was wrong. Batman the brave and the bold is a fun, well written show with enjoyable characters,and enjoyable stories. It carries on the legacy of quality DC comic TV series. Many fans of the older Batman series have never given this show a chance, based solely on the fact that that it is bright and colorful. Don't be one of these people; give this excellent show a chance.Now to address the issue of the half-assed releases that warner brothers seems adamant on giving this show. Before this, there were four single disc releases that only had 4 episodes on each; they each cost around 12-15 dollars and had no special features. Those releases were a joke, and many will say this one isn't much better. With only thirteen of the twenty-six episodes of season one, and with no special features what so ever, many consumers may say to avoid this release. Do not listen to them!For fifteen dollars, you are getting 13 great episodes. Are they in HD? No. Are there special features? No. But for the price you pay, what you get isn't a bad deal. Is it the deal we deserve? No. But if no one buys this release because they are waiting for the full season, they may be in for a nasty surprise. WB has no problem with never releasing the rest of this excellent series; ask the fans of the legion of superheroes. Though I was hoping for a full season release, in HD, I will take this, gladly. It is cheap enough that WHEN I purchase the full season in HD, I won't feel bad.This is a wonderful show on in a time when there are very few worthwhile cartoons on. Considering what came before it, this release is a good deal, and will tide you over until WB decides to pull their money grubbing heads out of their butts, and realize that if they want people to buy their products, they have to at the very least make the releases like this. At the VERY least. Buy it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'll be honest I'm a little tired of DC only showcasing their big guns of Batman and Superman. When I first heard of this show I thought it was a cheesy idea playing off the Adam West campy Batman show and wouldn't be worth watching.I gave it a chance simply because of the opening roster of guest stars like Green Arrow, Blue Beetle, and Kite Man. I was intrigued to see how these guys would be played. After the first few episodes I began to realise that this show is not about Batman, it's one giant brilliant homeage to all of the unknown and (criminaly) unloved characters of the DC Universe. The writing is genius it takes some of the most rediculous characters and concepts and turns them into amazing attention grabbing plots and twists that make you more then eager to watch the next episode.The use of the opening Teaser before each episode to showcase an upcoming villain or hero (or both) is fantastic, it gets you interested to keep watching the show in hopes that the characters will come back later. (Best surprise for me being The Question showing up in season 1 part 2).As a show Brave and the Bold is brilliant and the DVD is worth it for the episodes alone. My only dissapointment in this purchase is there's absolutely no special features. I would love to have seen some cast and crew interviews thrown in just to have some insight into why certain decisions were made and what made them pick each character for what reason.I'm ok with a split season, as quite honestly the set felt like a full season anyway. It's the lack of any kind of extras at all that was dissapointing. Still for 15 bucks it's definately worth it.
Title: N/A
